Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Charge Transport in Confined Molecular Assemblies
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this collaborative project, funded by the Macromolecular, Supramolecular and Nanochemistry Program of the Chemistry Division, James D. Batteas at Texas A & M University and Charles Michael Drain at Hunter College of the City University of New York will design, synthesize and evaluate the conductive properties of porphyrinoids assembled on surfaces. Using directed assembly approaches to position molecules on surfaces, the team will examine: 1) how molecular connectivity and local molecular interactions (i.e. environment, nearest neighbor interactions) can be used to influence electron transport behavior and 2) how spatial confinement influences the assembly of molecules on surfaces in nanoscopic junctions. The overarching goal of this research is to develop a clear understanding of the role each part of the electroactive porphyrinoid, the substrate, and the environment, plays in the electronic properties of molecular based electronic devices. Furthering the understanding of these synergistic effects will enable the rational design of potential More-than-Moore devices, including enhanced photovoltaics, chemical sensors and molecular electronics.

This work addresses a key intermediate of nanoscale molecular assemblies whose properties may show unique electrical behavior due to spatial confinement. Importantly, this work bridges the gap between single molecule and monolayer measurements where little research has been conducted. Students participating in this project will receive multidisciplinary training in materials science, nanoscience, surface chemistry and physics from both a theoretical and experimental perspective, allowing them to develop proficiency in multiple arenas. The outcomes of this work will be widely disseminated to a broad audience through a range of scientific publications and presentations made at informal public science events and research conferences. Aspects of the work will also be incorporated as demonstrations for elementary school students, with more advanced topics being brought right into the classrooms at Texas A & M University and Hunter College.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Over the past 4 years, this collaborative NSF project at Texas A&M University and Hunter College of the City University of New York on Charge Transport in Confined Molecular Assemblies has focused on addressing fundamental issues related to understanding electron transport between electroactive molecules and substrates that lie at the functional heart of many enabling technologies aimed at mitigating energy consumption or harnessing solar energy as components of dye sensitized solar cells. In particular we have focused on studies of electron transport in porphyrins, due to their rich photochemistry and their ubiquitous presence in nature as part of light harvesting architectures in photosynthesis. Our particular questions have been aimed at understanding the interplay of molecular architecture, electronic structure and how these molecules interact with each other when deposited on surfaces, with the goal of informing the design of new technologies that can have a significant impact on US energy independence and sustainability.

To address these fundamental questions a combination of experimental and computational methods were employed to examine how electrons flow through molecules that have been appended to surfaces in precise geometries.  The experimental studies included the design and synthesis of porphyrins with specific functional groups that would allow for their electronic structure to be systematically altered. We then examined how these molecules assembled on surfaces studied their charge transport (I-V) properties using a combination of atomic force microscopy (AFM) and scanning tunneling microscopy (STM). The use of these microscopies allowed us to examine these properties on the single molecule level, and to then build upon these structures using techniques for nanolithography to construct assemblies with precise molecular architectures to make nanoscaled islands of the porphyrins on surfaces. Computational studies using density functional theory (DFT) of the electronic properties of these molecules as afforded a better understanding of how the specific chemical changes can influence how these molecules can carry charge. Some of our key findings from these studies include: 1) that the transport mechanism could be shifted from an inefficient pure tunneling mechanism to a more efficient charge-hopping mechanism by creating molecular aggregates of ca. 5 – 10 nm in dimension on the surface; 2) that the stability of these islands depended greatly on the nearest-neighbor interactions of these molecules with each other and with their environment ; and 3) that the modular design of the fluorinated porphyrinoids can be exploited to develop platforms for novel sensors, photonic films and catalysts.  

Beyond the research activities supported by the grant, the more than 18 students who participated in this project received cross-disciplinary education and training in areas of materials science and engineering, surface chemistry, mechanics, nanoscience and nanotechnology.  Such broad training diversifies student backgrounds thereby preparing them for US initiatives in high technology. Students supported from this project have taken positions in academia, government labs, as well as in the technology sector (e.g. Intel Corporation). Our experiments have also resulted in the design a new laboratory experiment for undergraduates on tunneling in molecules that has been adopted at TAMU, the University of Texas-Austin and UCLA. This project has also involved the development of outreach activities through hands on demonstrations as part of the Chemistry Open House at Texas A&M University (TAMU), where we engaged elementary school children in hands on experiments on nanoscience, and at CUNY where hands on experiments in nanotechnology, laser diffraction, and radioactivity of local rocks were carried done at local middle schools.
